Pretty good. Almost lives up to the hype.

Listen, it's not perfect... but it's pretty good.
Here's the thing, the ratcheting mechanism is very nice, and the feel of the build quality is very good as well. There were, however, a couple of small things I would have expected to be better.

One was a molding point on the selector ring that wasn't trimmed off properly. Easy fix, just trimmed it with a razor, and now it's almost invisible, but I shouldn't have had to do that at this price point.

The other thing is how easily the divider in the bit storage can shift out of place from the 12-piece small mode to the six-piece normal bit size mode. a few times now, I opened up the bit storage to discover that the ring is rotated out of position, and the bits aren't quite in the right place. Not a big deal, but again, at this price point, I'd expect better.

One last thing, that isn't really a problem with the screwdriver, but rather, I wish, had been a design consideration, is how difficult it is to back turn a screw before you screw it in, to make sure the threads are lined up.
Obviously, it being a ratcheting driver, if you back turn the driver, the ratchet mechanism kicks in and it's hard to back-turn the screw tl make sure that your threads are lined up properly before you screw it in.
It would have been nice if there was some sort of momentary hold function to stop the ratchet from actuating temporarily, instead of having to manually move the selector ring into the middle position, which would take two hands.

All in all, it's a good tool, and mostly worth it, though I'd say slightly overhyped.
I don't regret the purchase, and would recommend it, if someone asked.

The one thing that left me longing was the absence of a security screw bit in the main lineup. Maybe it's just me being a tad picky, but in today's world of gadgetry, it's always good to be prepared for those tricky screws.
I'd also like to take a moment to commend the team at LTT for their consistent dedication and innovation. With each release, they continue to push the boundaries of what a screwdriver can be. As for their next exciting endeavour, I have my money on a 5-year R&D journey, and who knows what incredible features they'll come up with next? Perhaps, in the spirit of innovation, they could introduce a magnet that allows me to summon the screwdriver as if I were a tech-savvy force wielder. Just saying!
And, while we're on the topic of the LTT team, let's talk about Colton. He's often the centre of attention for better or worse, but he works... well, he's there, and we all know he's there for his pay check. So, Colton, keep doing your thing!

One unique aspect I've come to love is the packaging. On a cold winter night, there's something satisfying about burning the packaging and partaking in the ritual sacrificial screwdriver packaging burning dance. It's an experience like no other.

But, I digress. It's been quite a while since I've rambled on like this, hasn't it? So, if you've had the misfortune of reading this far, I encourage you to sit back, imagine, and embrace the quirks that make this LTT screwdriver a unique and worthwhile addition to any technician's toolbox.
While you sip your steaming brew of fine coffee I need a name for my smooth ratchety friend, I was thinking Frank, it seems like a Frank when I use it but if you have a better suggestion I am all ears!!
Well good bye for now and I look forward to reviewing the next!

Not perfect, but quite good.

First note: I am a craftsman, not a fanboy. This review is purely about the technical quality of the screwdriver, not the branding, color, etc.
Note 2: I own many multi-bit screwdrivers from craftsman, triplet, autoloader, ifixit and others.
The triplet / autoloaders are not ratcheting but offer faster bit change.
The Craftsman both autoloads and ratchets but is quite bulky.
One nameless model holds 18 bits but neither ratchets nor auto loads.
Many come with large sets of bits in a separate box or strip.

The LTT screwdriver is a good compromise. It holds 12 bits internally and can use hundreds of other standard 1/4 hex bits.
With a common adapter it can also use hundreds of the smaller standard 1/8 hex bits.
The ratchet forward force is less than many but I would wish that it were still lighter. The back force strength is prodigious, again a good compromise.
Fit and finish are excellent. Using a shorter than standard bit is a compromise to allow more bits to be stored without adding length.
But it can use any length bit and store some of them, albeit fewer than its own.
The freely rotating rear end cap is a nice feature that is rare on this big a driver. It is useful where I need to apply heavy downforce while turning a Philips.
All in all a good useful tool. A price somewhat higher than comfortable but acceptable for a specialty item.

I was lucky enough to be able to buy myself one of these astoundingly well made ratcheting screwdrivers as a belated birthday present to myself. At just under £70 it was well into the luxury end of the range of tools I now own. That said, it is a real workhorse! I have been using the screwdriver for a few weeks now, and have not even considered using anything else, so much so that I have even given some of my older drivers to one of my local charity stores. The driver itself has an astonishingly strong magnet that prevents you losing anything you're screwing into place. Are there any drawbacks? No, not that I've found so far. No, the driver isn't the cheapest on the market, but neither is it the most expensive. Is it reliable? Definitely! Is it good value for money? Certainly! Personally, I think it's the best screwdriver available, regardless of price. The bits are extremely strong, and, unless you 'really' abuse them, will probably last you a lifetime.\n

Never really took screwdrivers into much consideration, aside from the iFixIt kits I knew were great for computer and electronics specifically. Since I always saw everyone else using regular standard screwdrivers, and the only specialty ones I owned either had flashlights or fancy holders for a few bits, I never imagined anything better. When LTT showed this, it sparked some interest, but I never thought I'd enjoy using it and question why I never considered getting something better long ago. Aside from working on computers and electronics, I do some woodworking, car body repair work, and handy work around my home, which this screwdriver has made much easier and feels better to do than using regular screwdrivers.

The build is strong and can handle damage you may end up encountering. I used the top of the storage as a hammer once, not my greatest idea at the time of laziness, but it did the job and the cuts I made on it weren't noticeable unless you look closely. The shaft I have also scraped up a little while salvaging car parts, but even less noticeable. Although after doing that I can understand why they didn't do the painted shaft more than the first run of it. I wish I would have bought that one, but the more I see it, the less I feel bad about it. Overall the bits are great, haven't worn out as easily as cheap ones and the magnet for the bits is great. The ratcheting works excellent, my only gripe about it would be that it can get stuck in between settings, specially easy to do it when you use it in narrow/small spaces and move it yourself. The popup enclosure holds up incredible, I first thought it wouldn't last too long and would weaken quickly, but has held up to the same feel as when I first opened it. The materials used feels overall high standard and the handle is nicely smooth, to the point that you can easily store it in your pocket.

Aside from the ratcheting I mentioned prior, there are a few minor issues I see with it, but they are situational. First, the build can scratch and damage easily on metals. When doing car part salvaging and working on my own is when I have gotten most damage on it. Also, it isn't ideal in all scenarios for working on a car, as it can either be too long or too fat depending on what you are doing. Funny enough, I'm writing this after the reveal of the small one coming out, so that one partially helps in the length category, but does seem to be still chunky from when Linus has shown it and the shaft is possibly too short at that point too. The other thing would be the bit compartment being a little too strong to open in my opinion. I feel a little weaker might have been better, but it might also have been a choice on their part after testing it. You can open it with one hand, but it takes practice, and not really comfortable or easy to do.

Overall, It's been spectacular! I'm looking forward to seeing if they make add-ons to use on it or material variations that can help on what I mentioned with metal scratching it more easily. I've found myself enjoying the use of it, and I am starting to copy Linus and carrying it in my pocket. Hope to see a fidget toy, as they eluded in WAN because of the ratcheting mechanism.

I'm no tool enthusiast, but this is one of the smoothest and most satisfying ratcheting screwdrivers I've used. I've used it for over a month now for auto, PC and networking services, and I can say it's a very nice tool to keep in a pocket. Definitely not heavy duty, while sturdy enough. Can't recommend using it for rougher tasks like vehicle engines. Still, I don't get the sense that it's going to fall apart on me or break if I apply a bit more pressure. It is just light in weight, which is part of what makes it nice.

The magnetic storage is very handy and the magnets themselves (bit carriage and driver tip) are surprisingly strong. The bits themselves are decent quality. Holding up rather well with the daily work use I've thrown at it. Figured the low profile bits would be weaker, but I guess not! Same with the plastic fins of the bit holder. Still holding strong.

Down sides? Only two things. First is that the cap at the base, which you grab to pull the bit carriage free, has developed a creak to it and spins freely of the carriage itself. Poked and prodded at it, and it doesn't seem any less structurally sound. Just a little bothersome. The other down side is that it doesn't come with Torx bits. That's...kind of surprising since it's a common bit for tech repair.

Overall it's a great (and comfortable) tool for a tech's carry-on arsenal. Pricey? A little, but good tools are and there's a lot that's been put into it.

Initially skeptical, now daily driver

Originally I had a couple dewalt ratchet screwdrivers and a snap-on. They are all pretty decent, but there’s a bunch of tiny things about them that are annoying.

The integrated bit storage with this screwdriver is definitely what I love most about it. The fact that it can fit all the bits that came with it but is still compatible with other standard sized bits is extremely nice. The magnet is also worth its weight compared to my crappy dewalt that can barely hold a single screw unless the driver bit is not attached.

I was initially skeptical, especially considering it was from a YouTuber as the price seemed a bit high. However, I heard some good things about it but was officially sold on it when I watched the video that went through the entire process and why it took so long. That showed me that they put in a tremendous amount of effort and wouldn’t release it until they had it nearly perfected; both the design and manufacturing process.

I’ve only had it for a month and a half, but I’ve used it for building a server, changing all the switch plates, light switches, and outlets in my home, doing some work on my car, and a few other big projects. I can confidently say that whatever you call the rotated thing on the shaft to select the ratchet direction is perfect and I go for the LTT screwdriver every time because it just feels the most natural and intuitive in basically every way. Unlike other ratcheting screwdrivers, you actually turn it the direction you need for ratcheting a screw and I don’t have to think about it or test it out like every other screwdriver I’ve used.

After seeing Linus’ podcast about the external reviews and them disclosing some of the things they didn’t prioritize, I don’t think I ever noticed any of those issues. Even after becoming aware of those minor flaws, they’re so minor that I don’t even care about them (or even notice) when I use the screwdriver.

This screwdriver is perfect in all the categories I actually care about: ratchet mechanism, bit storage (+++), the magnet, shaft grip for rotating the shaft, direction for locking ratchet direction, the ergonomics, and the weight. This thing has a dedicated spot in my toolbox and my others will be donated to charity or given to a friend.

Nice work, I was skeptical, but I am extremely satisfied with my purchase. This was worth the price and I plan to buy another in the future as a backup in case I lose this one.
